author: Jacob Greber
title: RBA's Phil Lowe tips 'chain reaction' after yuan devaluation
text:
RBA deputy governor Philip Lowe: "We know that movements in exchange rates often set off a chain reaction of events which can be difficult to predict." Andrew Quilty Share on twitter by Jacob Greber The Reserve Bank of Australia has warned investors to be on guard for unexpected fallout from China's decision to devalue the yuan, which has triggered large shifts in exchange rates around the region.
While it was still to early to judge whether the dramatic devaluation would be of benefit to Australia if it helped strengthen its biggest trade partner, there are risks it may create near-term problems, the bank's second-most senior official said.
"We know that movements in exchange rates often set off a chain reaction of events which can be difficult to predict," said Reserve Bank deputy governor Philip Lowe.
"I think we've all to to watch what's going on very carefully, particularly in Asia, because many currencies have adjusted in the last couple of days.
Fallout from the decision to devalue the yuan by 3.5 per cent over two days pushed the Australian dollar to a six-year low and sent shudders through the local stockmarket .
All eyes will be on whether the People's Bank of China adds to the devaluation on Thursday at around 11.15am Sydney time.
Market watchers are widely split over the move, with many accusing China of escalating a global currency war by driving down its exchange rate in order to support its troubled export sector.
Others argue the move is a logical step towards making the yuan a free-floating currency - something many economists, policy makers and politicians in the West have been demanding for more than a decade.

View full Quote: Company Profile ASX Announcements Expand ASX Announcements View all announcements "More flexible currency' At an event in Perth late on Wednesday, Dr Lowe outlined three interpretations for China's actions, including a desire to unwind some of the large surge in the yuan's value over the past year or so.
"Another is that the growth momentum in China is a bit weaker than the authorities had expected, and the exchange rate adjustment is part of the correction for that, as has been the lowering of interest rates and increased spending on infrastructure," he said.
"And the third possible interpretation is that they're actually taking steps to move to a more market-based exchange rate.
"They've been saying for years that that was their intention, many international observers have been encouraging them in that direction, I think it's quite probable that this is actually a step towards a more flexible Chinese currency."
"All three interpretations probably have some element of truth to it, but this is a very recent development so I think it's too early to tell which of those isâ€¦or perhaps they're all correct."
Dr Lowe said it was difficult to judge the impact on Australia and that it would depend on what was driving the change of policy on the currency.
"If it supports growth in our largest trading partner, it's probably good," he said.
"If it's a positive sign about structural reform, a stronger commitment to markets, then that's ultimately good for China, and if it's good for China then it's probably good for us."
